Comment: Your emotional rant has nothing to do with science, but more with backwoods bias and beliefs.
Geneticist Ste Rikhardsson:
"The word “gender” is from the French word “genre” which means “type, class, kind”.Gender is a psychological construct whereas sex is a physical entity. The word “gender” is used wrongly by most people as a synonym for sex mainly because for 99% of people in the world, the two are the same. But just because they are the same for you, it doesn’t mean it is the same for everyone.
Even though there are two MAIN sexes, there are at least 16 types of sexes among humans. Many of these people are classed as “intersex”. Some people are born with XXY chromosomes or other combinations as well as ambiguous sex organs (sometimes totally ambiguous, sometimes with breasts and a penis, sometimes with a vagina, womb and flat chest, and sometimes with working or non-working sexual organs)."
This isn't "garbage," as you suggest. People are different. Differences should be respected.

Comment: Sorry Paul but I disagree about studs being more effective at all let alone MUCH (your emphasis, not mine) on glaze ice. In the world of physics the studded tire is a more consistent performer in the glaze ice battle in that it will give the same response whether treated gently or harshly---it has been my experience that the mentioned "slowing rapidly on glaze ice performance" is because of an acceleration dump or other abrupt input change and studs are more predictable. However given smooth handling and advance planning, siped tires will still beat them in performance. I have traversed hills and stopped at intersections that had defeated all around me many, many, times over the 45 years I have been using siping exclusively---needed my chains on the ground only 3 times over that period. I run an all season siped tire year around. And siping also aids in tire life--with the exception of gravel roads,--tire noise, and ride.

Comment: rammad012,

I take your point about the relative sizes of the 2 economies and the relative importance of NAFTA to each of these 2 economies.  However, this contest is not a zero sum game because both sides will suffer if relations become ugly.

Preferred access to the combined markets of Canada and Mexico is important to several important States and several key industries in the US and these domestic US interests will be our allies when push comes to shove provided Canada with Mexico make a good case in a resolute but reasonable manner.

Likewise, many important US corporations have important Canadian and/or Mexican interests they will want protected.

Further, overt bullying of Canada and Mexico over NAFTA will poison the well for US trade negotiations with many other nations with which the US wants to renegotiate trade agreements.  Realizing this will limit Trump's scope of action over NAFTA.

Comment: Since the early 1990s I've occasionally seen "Fix America First" bumper stickers.  This appears to be a paleoconservative slogan that urges redirection from foreign adventures and subservience to the global economy to fiscal and social soundness at home.  Like most old hippies, I find something in me that responds to that sort of nostalgia.

The reality, however, is that the United States, as it currently exists, cannot survive in anything like its current state if it permits powerful foreign combinations to form against it--e.g., China dominating all of East Asia, or Russia intimidating Europe.  On the eve of the Peloponnesian War, Pericles told the Athenians: "Nor is it any longer possible for you to give up this empire … Your empire is now like a tyranny: it may have been wrong to take it; it is certainly dangerous to let it go."  Our empire is quite different in character, consisting more of hundreds of pressure points than of broad territory, but the sentiment still fits.

Comment: But (most) capitalists don't deny that life is social, at all. They reject collectivism and central planning, yes, and emphasise that value reflects the subjective choices of individuals. However, each transaction in a market economy is a voluntary interaction between members of a society. The "market" is merely a reflection of society's aggregate economic interactions. Conversely, without society, the division of labour would not be possible, which precludes trade, which leaves us at a pre-historic level of individual subsistence. Society might be a collection of free individuals, rather than an abstract entity that ought to be directed and controlled, but without society, free-market capitalism could not exist.

Comment: All I have to say is that Gary Mason has no clue what he is talking about.  The vast majority of what he says is nothing more than unsupported speculation.  There is no data to support his hypothesis that speculation is driving up condominium prices.  Condominium prices have only  increased at half the rate of single family homes (based on MLS resale data).
The problem is a lack of supply of available land for the development of new housings.  There is lots of land designated for detached and semi-detach housing, but until all the services are in, the municipality has approved the development and, the big one actually issued building permits, that land is not available. 
BTW, there is absolutely nothing wrong with buying condominiums for rental purposes.  In fact, over the last 5 years about 60% of all condos have been purchased for rental purposes in the GTA (see CMHC data).  Without the condos there would be almost no new rental housing.  Thanks to rent controls, that will dry up to.

Comment: The author should really have dug more before writing this paper. The problem is not the cemetery itself, but the promoter, the Centre culturel islamique de Québec (CCIQ). The issue is controversial among Quebec City's Muslim community itself.
From the beginning, the CCIQ wanted to be the project's exclusive owner, casting aside all other Muslim shareholders, including the Association de la sépulture musulmane du Québec (ASMQ, or "Muslim Burial Association of Quebec"), which has a lot more experience in the matter. The Association, who dialogued with opponents of the CCIQ project, does not want a mosque to own exclusively a cemetery, because of a previous experience with a Muslim cemetery in Laval, left as a dump by the mosque that owns it. The ASMQ and other Muslim organization preferred a Muslim section in the Saint-Augustin-de-Desmaures cemetery, opened last week.
Death is a lucrative business, and exclusive ownership by the CCIQ would allow them to set foot in it.

Comment: Very well said!  

Our economy is more dependent on international and US economic trends and financial policies than on what our PMs and governments do to influence growth and solvency.  As Dalton Camp observed, "Washington makes the laws.  Ottawa makes the bi-laws".

But Canadian PMs and their policies can make the best or the worst of the global and US hands they are dealt.  PMs making the best of bad hands - as Harper did during the global melt down - tend to be trusted by the electorate and get re-elected.  Those who make the worst of bad hands lose their economic credibility and the trust of Canadians and are punished at the polls.

Trudeau 1.0 played his economic and fiscal hands disastrously and voters outside Quebec got wise to this and lost trust in his economic stewardship.  So he squeaked in by just 2 seats in 1972, lost in 1979, and doomed the Liberals to defeat in 1984.

Trudeau 2.0 seems to be following his father`s course and therefore can expect the same result.

Comment: The steps necessary to be financially successful are well-know, and almost universally recognized.  From my own experience, they are not quick or easy, but they are within the capabilities of most people, to varying degrees.  Avoid drugs, crime, and people who engage in them, and in my opinion, visible tattoos.  Graduate from high school, focusing additional efforts on clear speaking in English, creating written structured documents with a computer and a spell-checker, and basic math and financial literacy with a spreadsheet.  Then relentlessly pursue either a licensed construction trade or a 4-year college degree in a useful (marketable) field.  The military is an option for some.  All of these paths allow a person to afford a home, and other purchases.  Leaving for distant lands (like the ancient Polynesians sometimes did) may be painful but necessary.  You do not need to be perfect, but the more things you do correctly, the more success you will achieve.  There is no Santa or Jesus.

Comment: Look at the crazy rationalization people are going to here. I don't believe for a minute that people live in fear of deportation based on detained illegals being reported to ICE anymore than they live in fear of deportation generally. Yes, local governments are not tasked with enforcing a federal laws, but that's not what they're doing. The Sheriff's Department is simply notifying another law enforcement agency about a detainee's presence. This type of cooperation between agencies happens all the time and is within their power and authority. Of course it is also not a local city government's place to decide matters of US domestic policy, so who's really stepping outside their jurisdiction here? If Robin and Paul want to run for offices dealing with things besides zoning and development they should do that.

Comment: The two times I purchased a used car, I changed the oil right away as the oil was quite dark, so I can't understand a person buying a unknown used car and not doing the same. I changed the corroded battery terminals on the first and cleaned and lubed both cars connections. I sprayed all the door hinges and locks. I I used the first for two years and sold it for the same amount as I paid for it including maintenance, but not insurance. The second one I lost $7.000 over 6 years on depreciation and $3,000 on maintenance. I actually paid more on insurance on the second car than I paid for the car itself. All maintenance was at the dealer who replaced two sticking rear calipers under warranty, but not the destroyed rotor or the brake pads, hence the higher relative maintenance. I actually had to prove that the second caliper was sticking using an inflared thermometer reading on arrival at the dealer showing the 300°C reading before they changed it under warranty.

Comment: Under General Assembly Resolution 181, subsequently reaffirmed by Resolution 303, the United Nations officially recognizes Jerusalem as a "corpus separatum", which should ultimately be placed under a permanent international regime. 
Despite numerous Congressional resolutions, the United States does not recognize any part of Jerusalem as part of Israel.  However, both the United States and Great Britain (plus a few others), consider that the status of Jerusalem is to be resolved by both parties to the dispute in final settlement negotiations; thus, in practice, they ignore the existing UN “corpus separatum” resolutions.  
It appears that most of the world, including the Vatican, still accepts the dormant UN Resolutions rather than the current wishes of Israel and the US Congress.

Comment: In actual fact this debate has been going on for decades. In reality, the American companies have a legitimate beef. The stumpage fees in Canada are not what the American producers have to pay. 

It would be much better if Canada had gradually increased stumpage fees to defuse this argument. 
Each province could adopt a stumpage fee similar to that of producers in the bordering states directly south of them. 

Increased stumpage fees would have increased government revenue which could hopefully have been put to some good in Canada. Increased stumpage was never implemented because it would 'cripple' the Canadian lumber industry. 

As it is, countervailing duties imposed by the USA will cause the same hardships in the Canadian lumber industry but all the revenue lines the coffers of the US government.

We sign trade agreements, but somehow we do not expect the Americans to enforce the terms? 

Let's get real here.

Comment: Politicians always spend and prioritise water projects that involve ribbon cutting, with the illusion of bringing water to the people. Cape Town, like other metros in South Africa, has an ageing infrastructure and a far higher level (than officially reported) of non-revenue water (NRW) or unaccounted for water due to leaks, theft, inaccurate meters, watering etc. A historical focus on augmenting water supply without adequately addressing the NRW is like pouring more and more water into a leaking pipe. Historical spending on replacing ageing infrastructure has been grossly inadequate.

Comment: Err, just about everything?

Granted the U.S. is MOSTLY, though not exclusively, a two-party system so usually the winner in their first-past-the-post systems have 50% or more of the vote, but not always.  There have been Presidential Elections where the winner received as little as 43% of the popular vote (Bill Clinton in 1992, Richard Nixon in 1968) due to a third candidate receiving a lot of votes.

Of course the Presidential Election is not a direct FPTP but rather a state-by-state FPTP system in all but 2 States (Maine and Nebraska).  From there it is FPTP in terms of electoral college votes.

Congress and Senate seats are won using first past the post in most states though Louisiana, California and Washington use some form of two-round run-off voting for the House of Representatives and I believe a few states use such systems for the Senate.

Still, by and large, most elections in the U.S. are First Past the Post.

Comment: If we don't do something fast to limit the purchases by foreign buyers, then we will be holding a fire sale for them.  Domestic credit will be more limited by rate hikes, cuts to mortgage insurance (including portfolio insurance), stress testing, etc.  That will cause prices to sag, which would be very very good, in general.  But without limits on wealthy visa-holders who quasi-immigrate, buy property, have anchor babies, and never leave, we won't get the required downturn, AND they will get to buy at a discount.  You need to BOTH limit crazy domestic loans, and restrict buyers to Canadians and perhaps LEGAL permanent residents.  Look at a place like Calgary - in an oil price crash, the property market was kept far higher than it should have been by the outside money.  If you lost your job, I suppose being able to sell for a top price was a godsend, but it is not a normal cycle - usually, those in non-cyclical jobs would have had their opportunity to get in at a lower price.

Comment: I thought rents were expensive because of supply and demand. There is vacancy decontrol already so whatever a landlord can get for the unit they are allowed to charge. It is funny to hear arguments about how landlords have to charge more because of this or that regulation when in reality they just charge whatever they can get (like any market). Do you think that if landlords were allowed to evict tenants faster they would charge less than they could otherwise get for rent ? In Florida you can evict on 3 days notice but landlords still charge the same as here - whatever they can get.

Similarly why would you be able to "hike it " (ie rent above market) simply because the landlord has extra costs (increased condo fees, interest rates, delinquencies, maintenance). If it did work like that it would pretty well be a risk free business.

Comment: Who benefits from the levels and sources of immigration that we currently have (other than the immigrants themselves)?  The pat answer usually is that we need immigration to support our economy.  That is tantamount to saying that we have built an economic and cultural system that is unsustainable without cheap, imported labour (the previous term that fomented the US civil war being no longer acceptable).

If we reject the false premise that ever-increasing growth is desirable and sustainable, we can come to the realization that all we truly need is to maintain a replacement level of population (some would argue even that is too much).

We should be diverting the funding (direct and indirect) that is currently being poured into supporting immigrants to encouraging and supporting replacement level population growth from within.  And any necessary growth in economic output should be achieved through innovation and increases in productivity.  Smarter, not harder.

Comment: Finally, yes, minimum wage laws distort the labour market, and yes, they have been heavily studied.
.
But saying that market forces should simply be given free rein proves too much.  
.
For example: in human history over the last 9,000 years, only for less than 200 years has slavery been considered wrong.  De facto slavery is still common in parts of the world.  Free markets permit that.
.
So we prohibit child labour and enforce minimum standards for workplace health and safety, working hours, and so on.  All of it is "market distorting".
.
Not since the 1890's has there been as large an imbalance of power between private sector employers and individual workers as there is now.  Consider the ubiquity of unpaid internships.
.
As an issue of basic principles of economics, addressing the market failure to establish a minimum wage is not fundamentally different from prohibiting child labour.  They both arise from exactly the same phenomenon of gross inequality of bargaining power.

Comment: RE: Rob's retiree letter.  Just proves how different people are, I guess.  Truly is "one man's opinion."
My opinion: 
#1: I don't know how much the financial industry says I need.  And I don't care.  I know what we need, and we've got it. 
#2: We are busy in retirement.  As if "busy" is a state we should all aspire to.  Me?  I'd rather be relaxed and happy.  
#3: Stress reduction. Got a lot less and I'm a different person because of it.  One reason: not so busy.
#4: It's not hard to "spend down".  With us, it's impossible, because for the 7 or so years BEFORE retirement, we spent so little we squeaked...and that's how we could afford retirement. (We were NOT an extreme case; many folks in their early 60s will have to really curtail their spending--and kill their debt--immediately if they have any hope of retiring within the next ten years.). Now, we're spending UP and loving it.
#5 Nope...neither wife nor I needed any time to know how we wanted to live.
#6 Nervous? Nah.  Couldn't wait.

Comment: Apatrick,
You ask a fair question. For my part, I cannot help but fall back on what these bishops themselves teach, and ultimately, what they define as a sacrament. The church has developed a language to discuss the numinous. That language speaks of an outward sign associated with an inward change or grace...

Yes, there is emotion and rationality both required in the assessment of the scandal.  As to where the line between those two might be set in a satisfactory way, I suspect that point varies by individual, and over time. And THAT'S where trust, or lack of it, comes to play.  I think the author of the article is correct in the 3 numbered points in the article: the church's leadership has very much earned our skepticism. I suspect that in many/most human relationships, after there is an injury, it takes more that just time to repair. The offending party must work to restore that trust, assuring both at the emotional level, AND the rational.  The bishops have a lot more to do.

Comment: Peeing in the park/alley when you think no one is looking is not an offense that requires registration as a sex offender in the State of Colorado. It does not meet the elements of Indecent Exposure, which requires a KNOWING exposure of genitals to the view of another person when done with the intent to arouse. It also does not meet the elements of Public Indecency (which only requires registration after a second conviction within 5 years), which requires a KNOWING exposure of genitals to the view of another person.

Also, the juvenile sex offender registry is not made available to the public in the same way as the adult sex offender registry. And first-time juvenile sex offenders are able to petition for de-registration once they have successfully completed their sentence.

Comment: Before the interstate system, US-Highway 40 was one of two principal highways serving the Denver area. US-Highway 40 is Colfax. The idea for I-70 then was, not go through the heart of downtown like Colfax, but keep parallel to the north for the most direct route between Golden (and the mountains) and the airport, and to the east, for moving military or commercial goods. 

The stock yards were located along the route, the Denver Coliseum was already in existence, and use. I-70 made travel to each easier, faster, and without overloading surface streets. I-70 was built to keep traffic close to Denver, not to push the main east-west route several miles away from it, making travel times and distance longer.

Denver wouldn't look the same if I-70 had been built across Adams County. Businesses would've located near it, to take advantage of it, and the potential growth with it.

Comment: The engine of capitalism (or for that matter any free enterprise system) is Adam Smith's  observation of the "Invisible  Hand ".Indeed it seems it is the engine of political democracy as well. The Invisible Hand is by definition not a monolith but the result of innumerable human components each seeking its "own best interest" which results in a position/conclusion as to what is in the best interest of the majority.  Clearly this recognizes there is a minority but that minority is also made up of various different interests , none of which carried the day or has a consensus.

If you want to effectively pursue the goals of "social justice" the concept of the Invisible Hand requires that you work to achieve those goals at the individual level. Promoting top down government control is a grand approach when it is only the granular/individual level  that actually effects real change. Change the hearts and minds of the individual and you will get the effective change you desire in Capitalism.

Comment: Per capita is misleading because most of the new people are moving into places where RTD doesn't serve well. That's not to say that RTD doesn't have a variety of issues that are producing weak ridership, but I don't think the fares are really why. For most people it's just not a good logistical fit.

And as I said, even just keeping your car but driving it less means significant savings. A difference in 5000 miles not driven/year means $hundreds in gas savings, $hundreds more in maintenance cost saved, and good chance of $thousands in parking costs averted.  And that doesn't even count the biggest savings -- delaying the need for spending tens of $thousands to replace the vehicle as quickly.  Figure somewhere between $2000-$3000/yr cost for a typical car when the purchase price is averaged over the life of ownership. Unless it's your LAST car, delaying the purchase of the next one is real savings.

Comment: Japan has been in a major economic downturn (depression) for the past 30 years!!  Ever heard of the lost decade(s)?  What ever you do, don't bring up Japan's GDP!

Japan imports their energy (75% of which is coal/oil/gas).  Their energy use per capita is quite high compared to other advanced countries (because they use the energy to "make stuff").  Denmark also sources about an 80% of it's energy from fossil fuels.  It also uses quite a bit of energy, per capita, about half of Americans, and the same as France, Ireland, Italy or Israel and about six times India or Vietnam. 

Japan spends more than the US on education funding (8 vs 11 thousand/student).  I guess the US has it all: energy, education; domestic production with all that new fracking...

Comment: Another issue we should be concerned with, is Trump's discretionary drug use. Trump has taken Propecia (finasteride) - to help prevent male pattern baldness - for many years, according to a report released by his doctor.

Comment: Re:  Confederate Monuments and the Power of Absence.

Some good ideas here about what to do with Confederate statues that seem to dot the landscape, especially in the South.  Sarah Beetham, assistant professor of art history at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, in particular makes a powerful suggestion:  Remove the statue but leave the pedestal.  “I actually find the idea of these empty pedestals being there to be really exciting, because they are charged spaces, because that removal is going to create something that people have to think about,” she says, “What does an empty pedestal mean? What are the possibilities for art on an empty pedestal?”

I think this is a powerful idea.  Even better, for many of the Robert E. Lee statues for example, would be to remove the rider from the horse and leave the statue of the riderless horse.  It leaves an impression of an instrument of power and movement being leaderless, which has been a problem in Southern States for decades.

Comment: My guess is that if Mr. Hodginkson wasn't directing his anger at the president and the Republican party, he'd have been directing it somewhere else. People with the kind of internal turmoil that spills over into homicidal rage have issues that go well beyond the state of political discourse.

Still, I have no doubt the current climate of animosity and uncivil rhetoric exacerbates this kind of thing. And, in all honesty, that's my biggest problem with the current administration. Most presidents let their emotions get the better of them at weak moments, but we've never before (at least in my lifetime, going back to Eisenhower) had a president whose default mode was one of incivility and verbal attack toward those with whom he disagrees. It is a big concern.

All sides of the political conversation need to ratchet it down. No question of it. But if that doesn't get modeled at the top level of government, is anything likely to change?

Comment: Not to be too anal, but you mean VPSO (Village Public Safety Officer), not VSPO. And I believe Wassillie, the victim, was a VPO (Village Police Officer), not a VPSO. There is a big difference. A VPSO goes through state training & is recognized & supervised & paid by the state. There are way more VPOs than VPSOs. VPOs get a lot less training, & none of it is from the state that I know of. VPOs get lower pay, & VPOs are not officially recognized by the state due to the state's  opposition to tribal sovereignty. VPOs are paid & supervised by tribal councils. VPOs have high turnover & are often very young guys. VPSOs are meant to be a career option & have longer term professionals, generally. Both jobs are very tough & involve putting yourself in danger without a gun. High stress & low pay. Lots of alcohol-fueled domestic disputes, sometimes relatives. 

And to #3, yes the booze came from Bethel, the only hub here. The villages all vote to be dry but BET lets it pour in & profits from it.

Comment: In comments on an article that appeared yesterday, the R. v. N.S. ruling was used by some in an apparent attempt to argue that fundamental rights can't be infringed, which in my opinion is simply wrong. I also think the case has only marginal relevance where a general infringement is being pursued in the courts on grounds of an important societal objective and/or interest. R. v. Oakes presents an incidental Charter conflict test relating to a very specific pre-existing provision in the criminal code, but neither it nor N.S is as relevant or analogous to the Quebec face veil ban as is Keegstra, which addresses the specific issue of whether a deliberately legislated infringement of a fundamental right can be upheld where an important and overriding societal objective is argued to justify the infringement.

Comment: The era when I felt I could go out for a safe and leisurely evening stroll in this town disappeared about twenty years ago with the rise of the transient tide. Even in my senior years, however, I'm not willing to give up the freedom I paid for as a veteran and taxpayer to travel freely in the town I live in and support.

When I must or choose to go out in Eugene at night, especially later or downtown, I keep my car locked while driving, take care where I park, arm with a small intense flashlight and mace or small pistol, stay off my phone, and practice absolute awareness every minute. A few times when the "vibes" were bad, I've warned strangers not to closely approach me.

In the on-going discussion of how to make downtown Eugene less intimidating and dangerous, our decision makers should all take a few late night strolls through our downtown. It can be an eye opener!

Comment: Back in the olden days, you actually did get a 25 year term on a 25 year mortgage.

The problem is that lenders tend to finance your mortgage by borrowing the money at much shorter terms.  The way they make their money is off the spread between borrowing from someone else and lending to you.

Well, back in the olden days, my father got a mortgage with a 25 year term at something like 6% or 7%.

In 1980, short term interest rates spiked at 22%.

My father's mortgage lender was begging him to pay his mortgage off sooner.  After all, they were BORROWING money at double digit interest rates so they could, in effect, LOAN it to him at single digit interest rates.

Around that time, a lot of mortgage companies were going bankrupt.

Now do you understand why lenders don't like 25 year terms on mortgages?

Comment: Not mentioned is the recovery plan that federal officials will expect from the city by 30 April. If that plan is for conversion of steel wheels on steel rails (SWSR) technology to urban magnetic levitation (maglev), the 20-mile alignment, all of the stations (even if there are too many), the Pearl Highlands transit center, and a mix of 20 four-car SWSR and maglev trains all can be delivered for funding available through 2027. SWSR trains could provide service to a convenient turn-around point such as Aloha Stadium. Maglevs would be able to operate on all 20 miles, including the ten or so miles of maglev-only guideway through midtown Honolulu. Ignoring American designed maglev at this point would only compound the huge mistake made in 2008 when the Japanese maglev was not allowed to compete. That was bad enough; this time, it would be unethical to again disregard even more modern technology.

Comment: Many Asian women did indeed provide “comfort” services to the Japanese Imperial Forces during World War II, but I do not believe they did it at the point of a gun nor was it sexual slavery.    Throughout history, military forces have had no problem finding “comfort women” regardless of the country in which they operated and they were able to find them without kidnapping, coercion or threats of any kind.  Wars create horrible conditions which cause people to resort to often unthinkable means to survive.  For many women, it was the use of their bodies, and there usually was more supply than demand.  I personally witness this during the Korean War and during two years in Vietnam.  Some members of the Imperial Japanese forces no doubt forced women to have sex, which, of course, is rape, but I believe the “comfort women” who served the Imperial Japanese forces in brothels that sprung up and operated near Japanese bases did so voluntarily for pay.

Comment: Or, to put it in objective non-inflammatory terms, Pius XI, after 59 years of a stalemate with the Italian state due to the seizure of the Vatican State by King Victor Emmanuel II, directed Cardinal Pacelli to complete negotiations on regularizing relations with Italy.

In 1929, the Pope supervised the signing of the resulting Lateran Treaties with the Italian government, in which the Vatican City was given sovereignty as an independent nation in return for the Vatican relinquishing its claim to the former territories of the Papal States.

Catholicism was recognized as the sole religion of the state, Italy paid salaries to priests and bishops, gave civil recognition to church marriages (previously couples had to have a civil ceremony), and brought religious instruction into the public schools.

The Church was not obligated its support the Fascist regime.

Pius XI died ten years later at the age of 81.

Comment: Based on personal experience, I'd agree somewhat with the statement: “In exchange for a little less security of tenancy, the renters gain a massive increase in resiliency and flexibility,” Mr. Robertson writes. 

We sold our Calgary home in the wake of the 08 crisis--by choice.  We needed to save a whole lot of money fairly quickly (within ten years, we figured) and we couldn't do it with typical home-owner costs and--in our case--paying strata and pool fees, too.  So: sold.  

Rented a much bigger (1,700 sq. ft.) newer (5 years old) home for $1,500 a mo. We started saving immediately, but because--we believe--we were great tenants for out-of-province landlords, we also had MORE security--rent never increased in the 6 years we lived in the place. When oil prices declined--moved out.  Landlord woes! They wanted to increase the rent to $1,700 a month.  Management company suggested they'd be lucky to get a tenant for $1,300! Somebody got a bargain. A RENTAL bargain.

Comment: A thorough study of the development of our jury system might surprise you.  

Today, we bend over backwards to ensure a juror knows nothing about a case before being selected to be a juror.   

"Medieval juries were self-informing, in that individuals were chosen as jurors because they either knew the parties and the facts, or they had the duty to discover them. This spared the government the cost of fact-finding.  Over time, English juries became less self-informing and relied more on the trial itself for information on the case. Jurors remained free to investigate cases on their own until the 17th century."

Comment: Excellent! The introduction of Rep. Holvey's House Bill 2369 could not be better timed. As many of us gear up for the upcoming "March For Science" on April 22, it is *vital* that we suffer no illusions that anti-science Realpoliticking is any less of a crisis on the Left as it is on the Right. And this proposed legislation could not possibly serve as a more fitting "Exhibit A" to this effect.

Here are only a few of the many "impacts of products or seeds that are genetically engineered"...

1) an 85%  *decrease* of insecticide spray

2) an overall 37% *decrease* of pesticides overall

3) MUCH safer herbicides for weed control (the LD50 for Roundup's active ingredient, glyphosate, is 5600 mg/kg... less toxic than table salt!). Non-GMO crops --- including *organic* --- use more pesticides than "GMO" strains, many of which are considerably more toxic.

You also need to remember that life in America has not been the same for every class of people. You look back and think "the good ol' days" but many people look back and fear those times. 

I'm for the values you state, but not at the expense of vulnerable populations among us. Those shared values should unite us all and not favor a single denomination or religion. We should be able to come together with our differences in tact.

Comment: I think the media have some responsibility here too. I well remember a daytime television show where two doctors were debating the use of narcotics in chronic and recurring conditions like migraines and fibromyalgia. The audience had obviously been cherry-picked in advance and members ended up screaming at the physician who was cautioning against the use of narcotics. He was quite humiliated by the audience and the host, and essentially told to "educate" himself. The usual advice was also given by the host at the end of the show - if your doctor doesn't agree with this, get a new doctor who does. 

I had trouble with this issue as a FP too. I remember being told in the 1980s by a well-respected palliative care physician that narcotics were not addictive if the pain was genuine. I couldn't  believe it, but the myth grew over the following 10 years because people were being told what they wanted to believe.

Comment: There seems to be a lot of confusion about the Ninth Circuit court's ruling yesterday. They did NOT rule on the legality/constitutionality of Trump's travel ban. That case has yet not been heard by the lower court. There has been no ruling and therefore nothing yet for an appeal court to consider.

What the White House appealed was the lower court's imposition of a temporary restraining order. That judge--a Republican!--imposed the TRO until the case can be heard. At that point, he will either rule the ban constitutional and lift the TRO or strike down the ban and issue a permanent injunction.

TROs are not all that uncommon. The idea here is to suspend the potentially illegal action until the court can rule on it. The travel ban is only in place for 90-120 days and could easily expire before the case is even heard. By that point, the damage is already done.

Comment: Even in “Catholic” countries, the Church preferred to have its clerics enjoy the privilege of clergy whereby they could only be tried in the canonical courts. The 1953 Concordat with Franco in Spain provided that a bishop could only be put on trial in a civil court with the consent of the Vatican, and priests with the consent of the bishop.  The trial, if agreed to, was not to be publicised. The 1973 concordat with Colombia still provides that bishops can only be tried by the canonical Courts. Priests on the other hand can be tried in State Courts but the proceedings are not to be publicised. I am not aware of any similar concordat with other South American countries. One of the reasons for the imposition of secrecy under canon law, in my opinion, is that the same result could be achieved by a cover up in countries unsympathetic to similar concordats. If the State did not know about these crimes, the matter could be dealt with exclusively in the canonical courts.

Comment: The answer is not found explicitly stated in the state or federal constitutions. This was a big debate between Federalists and Anti-Federalists, whether or not the U.S. Constitution was sufficient to guard the natural rights of man. In Federalist papers 45 and 84 as well as in so many other articulations throughout the texts Hamilton and Madison argued that the Federal default position was an absence of power and clearly all authority not clearly granted was reserved to the States and Individuals that comprised the compact.

Land and resource ownership is by default the inheritance of the common man in this nation. The only way to fully understand the concept is to understand it as the founders did by reading the great philosophers chiefly John Locke.

Why would man in his natural state consent to a government that does not first offer him protection and equal opportunity? The vast majority in the U.S. were farmers, all they understood of opportunity was access to natural resources.

Comment: "The House State Affairs Committee approved a measure Thursday that would place Alaska into the Pacific Time Zone and remove the state from daylight saving time. 

The bill would shift all of Alaska to one time zone — it currently has two — bringing it into alignment with the West Coast states. That would trigger the exemption from daylight saving time."

ok i have no problem losing daylight savings time, but the way this is worded is wrong. that means for the summer months when they are sprung forward, no problem, but what happens when they fall back? then calif, ore and wash are an hour behind us? and now we are in the mtn time zone the same as denver? 

the correct way to solve getting rid of daylight savings time is to spring forward with everyone else and stay there. so for the summer months, we are still one hr behind the pacific time zone as we are now. but when they fall back in the winter, then we are in the pacific time zone, same as california. problem solved!

Along with everything else, your body gradually turns into something that at best you feel no connection to and at worst actively horrifies you. (There are different kinds of transgender people.) Because, while your sex can't be changed (non-trans people always think trans folks don't know that,) neither can your gender be changed. Comment: I believe that for people living in large cities and especially in the GTA, where housing costs and rents have exploded in recent years, a $15 minimum wage is a fair(er) wage. But the effects of quickly raising the minimum wage to this level could be quite problematic. Small businesses will be particularly hard hit. Also, low-wage workers could suffer, as has been the case in Seattle, where businesses absorbed the initial wage hike in the graduated scheme implemented in that city, but eventually as the wage level increased further staffing was cut back and the precariously employed reportedly ended up getting fewer hours and less income. So my advice would be to implement the minimum wage more gradually, at not more than $1/hr per year, and examine the impacts before proceeding with further large increases. This, Ms. Wynne shouldn't be about your re-election but instead should focus on a broader economic view.

Comment: I'm with you, Denby.  Back in hanabata days, if it was a big mango season those paper bags would have to be sneaked onto your neighbors' porches in the dead of night, on tiptoe so as not to wake up their dog (or rooster).  Then the morning after that, you might be able to recognize some of the mangoes that showed up in the bag on YOUR porch.

Comment: It's easy to increase natural resources per person by limiting immigration. It's not clear that the same is true for financial resources. Less people means a smaller economy, less cross-pollination of ideas and fewer opportunities for economies of scale. There's a reason why immigration isn't just supported by big business but by parties of all stripes, because we can only pay for stuff if we're earning enough compared to other countries.
Personally, I'd rather be able to afford an HTC phone made in Taiwan, a PS4 made in Japan, a ThinkPad made in China, and maybe someday a Tesla made in the USA. If that means giving up a piece of arable land in return, I'm quite okay with that.
Immigration keeps importing young, hardworking people whose taxes and demographics sustain our welfare system. We get them for free without having to pay for any of their daycare or decade-long education. All we need to do for this is to give them a spot in society. I think that's a good trade-off.

Comment: Higher credit card balances are a function of spending more than you make, or for some other reason choosing not to pay of the full balance each month. Debit card transaction fees may indeed encourage more use of credit cards, and as a by product of that some people may indeed over spend more resulting in higher carried balances.

That said I don't know why anyone would use a debit card given the choice of paying with a credit card.  Lots of no fee credit cards offering decent cash back, meaning that you not only avoid paying bank fees but you get paid for leaving your cash in your account for between 20 and 50 days (depending on when you purchase and when your payment is due).

Comment: I disagree with the assertion that "If one must have a gun, you still have a moral obligation to not shoot it." Nonsense. The assailant with the knife had a moral obligation not to threaten anyone with it and rob them. He ignored that obligation and our laws that reflect that.

Instead of a moral obligation, the man with the gun had a difficult choice: fire or not fire. He chose not to fire, and as it happens, things turned out well. Sometimes they don't, and the assailant they let escape ends up killing an unarmed robbery victim a short while later.

Carrying a firearm for protection is not a no-brainer. You do have to train yourself, and consider the possible outcomes and your willingness to undergo them. Shooting someone, even a thief or murderer, carries a huge cost psychologically and financially, even if you are clearly in the right. But that may be better than what your family must endure should you fail to defend them or yourself in such a situation.

Comment: According to the Grammarian, I am a century out of date by using busses.

"In 21st-century English, buses is the preferred plural of the noun bus. Busses appears occasionally, and dictionaries list it as a secondary spelling, but it’s been out of favor for over a century. This is true in all main varieties of English.

After bus emerged in the 19th century as an abbreviation of omnibus, buses and busses (the logical plural of buss, an early alternative spelling of bus) vied for dominance for several decades. By the early 20th century, though, buses was the clear winner, and it has steadily become more prevalent. Today, buses appears on the web about 15 times for every instance of busses.

Comment: Hywnsytl, a part of me agrees with you. You make sense. But the other part says Coach Rolo understands people and motivation. His message is clear to all the players -- "Work hard and good things follow." If he didn't reward work ethic, then a different message is clear -- "Doesn't matter how hard you work. Only the talented will be rewarded." This message is fine for the NFL where money talks. But this is college ball, and the players are students first. The coach's job is to make them believe they can grow if they work hard -- and if they work hard enough, they can win.  We've seen, time and again, coaches taking average players and motivating them to play beyond their individual capacity.  That's the definition of a great coach, and we're lucky to have had our share of really great ones -- in my time: Tomey, Wags, and June.  And now we have Rolo, and all the signs say he is destined for greatness, too.

Comment: Not that I agree with it, but what exactly is the problem with Trump's withdrawal from the Paris agreement?  The other countries will (supposedly) carry on with their commitments without the US, and progress will be made.  Many US jurisdictions will invoke their own CC measures anyway, and so will many corporations (because there is a business case for doing so, Volvo being a recent example).  Coal-fired power plants won't return with natural gas being cheap and cleaner.

Is there a real risk that the other 19 will say "If the US is out, then so are we"?    If not, then why fuss over what Trump says or does on the issue?  Someone may persuade me otherwise, but it's hard not to think that Trump's position on the issue is almost irrelevant....and certainly not worth getting twisted into a knot over.

Comment: Expect the US to raise such subsidies as an issue to be resolved during the upcoming NAFTA talks with Canada.  

It is useful to recall in that context that from the 1950s to the present the US has heavily subsidized the US aircraft industry in several ways. First, the US Government works in close cooperation with US airplane manufacturers and commercial carriers from the inception of choices made in designing and setting specifications for new or updated models of aircraft with the result that many military aircraft have a very close civilian analog.  This means that design and production costs for both civilian and military models and efficiencies of scale in production are kept to a minimum and, more to the point, the US Government foots much of the bill for many costs for US production of civilian aircraft.

The US also subsidizes foreign purchases of US produced military aircraft and puts strong pressure on its allies to make such purchases.
